Disclaimer: This review will count for both seasons of the series.
I’m sure anyone who is genuinely reading this review knows what Fate/Zero is, as it has gained a large following in the anime community, from, what only I could discern being the high quality of the animation and the fanbase it has already received from its predecessor series, what many often refer to as Deen/Stay Night. It has been generally positively reviewed by the community, but, as one could most definitely tell from my score of it, I don’t particularly follow that train of thought. This is due, in a brief exposition for those whodon’t have the patience for long reviews, to the uselessness of many of its character, the somewhat pretentious philosophy of said characters, and the general slow and not well executed thought. However, I will say that it does have good ideas, they are just not properly fleshed out to the point where I can award the show points for it. The premise means nothing if there is bad execution. With that being said, allow me to get into the actual review.


Characters:

Many characters in the show have their backstory shown and their goals explained (if not drastically then at least in part), however, this in and of itself does not justify being warranted as having good characters. The first main point against the quality of these characters is there general uselessness. Many, such as Lancer, Archibald, Sola-Ui, Irisviel, Waver, etc., do not have any main role to serve in the show. That is not to say that all characters should make a considerable donation to the plot, but they should at least be used in a way where they felt they had some limited impact. Tokiomi, for instance, was said to have had an infallible plan and was pushed to be one of the main contributors to the story, but never did anything except burn Kariya and get killed by Kirei. 

	There are also instances in the show where character development is shown. Waver developed the most in the show and got a surprising amount of screentime considering he was one of the lesser mages in the main characters. Saber also had character development, however, it didn’t really feel like it made much sense. She let a few sentence speech by Rider change her views on her philosophy that she had followed for many years, and could have easily been told of her oversight by Lancelot, who seemingly left the roundtable instead of just telling Saber how he really felt. The worst offender of bad character development is Kirei, who basically got told by Gilgamesh what to do, and then ended in desiring to make people suffer, a very bland and typical villainesc goal for a series that is supposed to have grey characters.

	The historical inconsistencies, such as Arthur’s Gender, his existence as a whole, and Iskander’s height were a little off-putting, but that is just a nitpick. It also bugs me that they had so many better historical figures to chose from then what they chose. Wouldn’t it be better to have Arthuria face off against, say, William the Conqueror. That sure would be interesting. Wasted potential, I suppose.

	The character’s sense of philosophy is always annoying. Irisviel basically has no reason for adhering to Emiya’s philosophy, and Emiya himself has a very silly goal, considering that he wants to save humanity by killing all who stand in his way, a thing a normal human being would clearly find to be repulsive. The whole honor thing as spouted by Lancer and Saber is basically a time waster and a method from the authors to make the characters “dance their dance” as they say. There is also Caster’s philosophy, which is so stupid it doesn’t even deserve mentioning. There should always a motive that would be befitting of a human to do their own actions, which is certainly not what I see here. Anyway, that is enough rambling about the characters, let us move onward.


The Plot:

	The Plot drags its feet along in the first season and then shoots off like a rocket towards the end of the second season. The first season was almost entirely skippable, with the only things missing being the death of Assassin (not that they mattered to the show anyway), and the near death of Archibald, which I guess mattered but he instead died in the 2nd season after an entire sequence with Emiya that didn’t really matter. The conversation between Gilgamesh, Iskander, and Arthuria was also important in some ways.

	A minor thing was that they shoved in Emiya’s backstory in the middle of the 2nd season for practically no reason, considering that it had absolutely nothing to do with the events that were conspiring in the present. It was also boring as it moved far too fast and was basically edge lord material in the first episode. The 2nd episode was good for what it was, but if was still far too rushed.

	Another thing that bothered me was the powers that the characters were using. The masters were said to be all strong with magic (excluding Ryuunosuke and Waver), but the only people to ever show it were Tokiomi, Kariya, Archibald, and Emiya (and Kirei slightly but that doesn’t really count). Even when they did show their magical powers, it only mattered to the story and only caused damage when they were being used by Emiya. It made it feel like Emiya was so much powerful than everyone else and it killed the tension. If that were the case, all of the noble houses should’ve hired people like him instead of wasting times with these useless fools. The Servants also had the power to teleport and ride any vehicle they so desire (as explained by Arthuria in the first season), however, they never did. Gilgamesh could’ve easily wiped the competition and Rider could’ve defeated Saber if he didn’t just simply run away and actually decided to fight. It really kills the tension when you know that these characters could instantly defeat opponents but don’t due to the plot demanding so.

	The whole setting of the show also irks me. Why would the houses agree to send only a few men into battle when they could gather a literal magical army in order to claim the holy grail. Also, the holy grail was used before, in which case, what wishes did it grant and why doesn’t one magical family rule over the world at this point. Something like Emiya’s and the royal families’ ambitions should have already been carried out if the grail truly has unlimited power like the legend states. Also, everyone should already know that the grail has bad intentions if people have seen the wishes fulfilled before. There also very little possibility that the ever attentive governments of the world would not know about these magical abilities. It also doesn’t make sense why the Church would allow magic considering it was heavily panned by early church philosophers as being the work of the devil and his followers. 

	My other gripes with the story were already listed in the character section, so I will not bother to repeat them here, but I am sure I missed some and will have to come back to this later.


The Art/Animation:

	Despite the lack of good choreography in many of the fight scenes, the animation was good for the most part. The art style didn’t really fit the dark tone that the story was going for, but considering that the original Fate/Stay Night has these types of designs, there was really no way around that so I won’t fault them too much for that. It has good detail on most of everything and does sometimes give the impression that the surroundings could be an actual place while not losing the stylistic look of the original. Animation, however, can not save this series from being the disaster that it was. 


The Soundtrack:

	Nothing really to say here, I, personally, didn’t notice any pieces that were too memorable or too forgettable. The music fit well with the series, I suppose, and there was never a time where I thought the music was misplaced. The sound effects for the series are also fairly good. However, this should not be considered a major category to logically find the quality of any show, at least not to the same extent that the Story and Characters are.


Conclusion:

	Fate/Zero was a series that certainly had potential, but failed to capitalize on it. The plot felt contrived at points, and stupid at others. The characters had the potential to be written well, as the writers seem to have known what they were doing with a few of them, however, most were completely useless and felt as if they were more of an excuse to elongate the anime rather than to be genuinely good. The sound and animation are great, for the most part, and is probably the reason why you should watch this show if you decide to do so after reading this review. It certainly could have been a fantastic anime to have been remembered for years after, but instead ended up as another overhyped show that pops up once ever couple of years. At least, that is my educated opinion. I have been Kakorat859, and this has been Kakorat’s review of Fate/Zero. Be sure to be safe and have a nice day.

I am blown away by this anime. When my husband told me about the concept, I was skeptical to say the least. What? Mages that pair themselves with famous heroes from the past in order to pursue the holy grail? Excuse me? 
But, what I got in this anime was an extraordinarily complex look at the conflict in the human condition. It is a philosophical exploration of age-old questions regarding leadership, servanthood, love, evil, and the salvation of humanity. The action is fantastic and enhances, rather than detracts, from the story and character development. The animation is superb and the use of CG effects istastefully done and combines itself delicately with the animation. The music was BEAUTIFUL and I can't WAIT to get the soundtrack at my next opportunity. The openings and endings were gorgeous and memorable (I frequently get them stuck in my head). 


Though there were so many characters present in this show, I very easily grew extremely attached to all of them. There are deaths in this show and each one hit me hard (either in the emotionally vulnerably spots or in the mental pondering). In my opinion, this story is really about two opposing characters when you boil it down to its essence: Emiya Kiritsugu and Kotomine Kirei. 


(This is for the ENTIRE series (i.e. Season 1 and 2)


Kiritsugu's backstory episodes, for example, are literally the two best episodes of anime I have ever seen. 


If you are going into this expecting a fluffy, light, happy anime with lots of Dragon Ball Z-esque fights, you will be disappointed. This is literally a gold-standard anime that is the BEST of the BEST. I am still reeling over the ending and, though some may find it dark, I was impressed that they held nothing back and the feeling I was left with was one of battered and broken, but still present, hope.

This review is to cover both seasons of this anime. There is a lot of hype surrounding this series, and it does deserve good marks. This is a very visually appealing anime and it's filled with amazing action. I love some of the characters, and really love the concept. Since this is a prequel, it already had a solid fanbase when it was released. It's the crazed fan reviews that made me give this series a look.
From the beginning you're thrown from character to character as the story simply starts. There is a lot going on, but it's not difficult to follow. I feel thatit is missing a proper setup (probably due to it's prequel status). Visually, I was impressed from the start, but I had no attachment to any of the characters even after a few episodes. I had never seen Fate/Stay Night, and someone had recommended I watch this first to see them in chronological order. That may have been a mistake, however, I feel a story needs to at least have a good setup and minimal character development. This series brought up the different mages histories, but saying a character is one way and then showing it are two different things.


The main characters all flip flopped between good and evil personas, but the heroes were the saving grace for this series. They were consistently in character, and their desire to have honorable fights kept them the stars as the story trudged on. Every one of the mages played dirty at one point or another, which is understandable, but it made it difficult to root for any of them. 


This is not a happy tale, and if you've seen Fate/Stay Night then you already expect a depressing story to some degree. It has a dark feel throughout, and there's a lot of deceit and backstabbing as the mages attempt to win by any means necessary.


This particular series gets high marks on the art, sound and characters (though I feel more on the hero side), but I personally found the story/plot lacking in development and I wasn't waiting for each episode with any kind of anticipation. It's sort of the opposite of the series that chronologically follows (which is older so lacks in the art/sound but makes up in story and character development).


In short, it's a good anime and worth watching, but I would watch Fate/Stay Night before this one so you don't have to worry about setup and development.
